content.webTitle: Barack Obama rejects claims 2013 has been worst year of his presidency

fields.headline: Barack Obama rejects claims 2013 has been worst year of his presidency
fields.bodyText: Barack Obama rejected suggestions that 2013 had been his worst period as president in a year-end press conference dominated by criticism of his handling of healthcare reforms and the NSA surveillance scandal. “That's not how I think about it,” he told reporters in the White House briefing room. “We have had ups and downs, this room has recorded at least 15 near-death experiences. What I focus on each day is, are we moving the ball on the American people, families, to have a little more opportunity, a little more security … to feel as though they're moving ahead.” The president acknowledged that the rollout of the healthcare exchanges at the heart of the Affordable Care Act had been his biggest mistake, but insisted it would be forgotten over time as more and more Americans gained access to insurance. “The fact is, it didn't happen in the first month – the first six weeks – in a way that was acceptable,” he said. “We screwed up.” Some 500,000 Americans signed up to new insurance in the first three weeks of December, the White House claimed. Obama was also forced to defend a last-minute decision to suspend penalties for certain groups uninsured people who had failed to get policies, because of the problems with the online exchanges. He said the administration “just wanted to make sure that the hardship provision that's in the law” applied to people having trouble in this “transition”. The president blamed much of the lack of progress this year on key priorities such as gun control and immigration reform on Congress, but predicted that next year might be better following a recent bipartisan deal to pass the budget. “A lot of our legislative initiatives in Congress have not moved forward as we'd like,” he said. “It's too early to declare an outbreak of bipartisanship but we are not condemned to endless gridlock.” He also predicted that improving economic conditions would help unlock progress on a host of issues from unemployment to income inequality. “I believe 2014 will be a breakthrough year for America,” said Obama, in an upbeat opening statement about the economy. "We head into next year with an economy that’s stronger than it was when we started the year. More Americans are finding work and experiencing the pride of a paycheck." But the traumas of the past 12 months clearly weighed heavily on the president, who was repeatedly pressed about approval ratings at an all time low. “My polls have gone up and down at lot,” he said. “If I was interested in polling I would not have run for president.”
